bestBHT.bht: Seeing the darkness and prodigies during the crucifixion, the people’s attitudes were transformed, ceasing their mockery and leading to self-accusation. This remorse was later reignited by Peter’s preaching, reminding them of their role in Jesus’ crucifixion. While some saw Jesus as a righteous man, others viewed him merely as God's Son or a righteous individual. In the aftermath, the people returned to the city with somber minds, seeking solace in contemplation of this profound tragedy.

Henry Alford: The things which came to pass are the darkness and other prodigies, after which we have no more raillery:—men’s tempers are changed, and we here see the result.
Smote their breasts... a sign of self-accusation, at least for 'the time,—which is renewed on the preaching of Peter, Acts ii. 37.
Philip Schaff: No mention is made of the rulers. Jerusalem was crowded, and the 'multitudes' were great. This sight, or 'spectacle.'"
The things which were done. These put an end to mockery.

Returned smiting their breasts. In self-reproach, for they had cried out for His crucifixion. Luke alone speaks of this, but it is not implied that the people had taken no part in the previous mockery.
Archibald T. Robertson: Certainly (οντως). Really, old adverb from the participle ον from ειμ, to be. Used also in Luke 24:34 of the resurrection of Jesus.
A righteous man (δικαιος). Mark 15:39 (Matthew 27:54) which see, represents the centurion as saying θεου υιος (God's Son) which may mean to him little more than 'righteous man.'
Returned (υπεστρεφον). Imperfect active of υποστρεφω. See them slowly wending their way back to the city from this Tragedy of the Ages which they had witnessed in awe.
John Gill: beholding the things which were done... smote their breasts as conscious of guilt.
as fearing some dreadful judgment would fall upon them.
and returned; to the city, and to their own houses, where they might more seriously, and with the greater composure of mind, reflect on these things.
John Wesley: All the people — Who had not been actors therein, returned smiting their breasts - In testimony of sorrow.

bhtAttempts.bht: The events that occurred during the crucifixion were undeniably powerful, causing even the most hardened hearts to change. The people, seeing the darkness and prodigies, were no longer mocking, but instead felt self-accusation. This self-reproach continued when Peter preached, as they were reminded of their role in the crucifixion. Among the crowds, the centurion saw Jesus as a righteous man, although others may have seen him merely as a God's Son. In the aftermath of this profound tragedy, the people slowly made their way back to the city, deeply reflecting on what they had witnessed.

The crucifixion had a profound impact on the people, changing their attitudes and stirring feelings of self-accusation. Witnessing the darkness and other extraordinary events, they were no longer mocking. Peter's preaching later reignited their remorse for their role in Jesus' crucifixion. While some regarded Jesus as a righteous man, others saw him merely as God's Son. Reflecting on the tragedy they had witnessed, the people returned to the city with somber minds, contemplating the significance of what had transpired.

The profound impact of the crucifixion was evident in the changed attitudes of the people who witnessed it. As they saw the darkness and prodigies, their mockeries ceased, and feelings of self-accusation arose. The preaching of Peter later evoked a renewed sense of remorse for their involvement in Jesus' crucifixion. While some regarded Jesus as a righteous man, others merely saw him as God's Son. In the aftermath, the people slowly returned to the city, deeply reflecting on the transformative tragedy they had witnessed.

The crucifixion had a profound impact on the people, changing their attitudes and causing self-accusation. Witnessing the darkness and prodigies, they no longer mocked, but stood in awe. Peter's preaching later stirred up their remorse for their role in Jesus' crucifixion. While some saw Jesus as a righteous man, others perceived him as God's Son or merely a righteous individual. Contemplating what they had witnessed, the people returned to the city, their minds filled with reflection on this monumental event.

Seeing the darkness and prodigies during the crucifixion, the people’s attitudes were transformed, ceasing their mockery and leading to self-accusation. This remorse was later reignited by Peter’s preaching, reminding them of their role in Jesus’ crucifixion. While some saw Jesus as a righteous man, others viewed him merely as God's Son or a righteous individual. In the aftermath, the people returned to the city with somber minds, seeking solace in contemplation of this profound tragedy.
